supporting_text: The NAP mentions the need to contain antimicrobial resistance, a phenomenon affecting human health, animal health, plants and the environment.
The NAP includes actions such as improving awareness and understanding of AMR in human health.
The NAP includes specific interventions in the Responsible Use of Antimicrobials in animal health.
The NAP addresses environmental health through guidelines for biomedical waste and effluents.
The NAP includes actions related to agricultural practices and the use of antimicrobials in food production.
The NAP includes a monitoring and evaluation framework detailing process, output, and outcome indicators.
The NAP outlines specific targets and timelines for various activities over the five-year period.
The NAP does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes a budget section detailing the costs associated with implementing the various strategies and actions.
The NAP provides options for resource mobilization and budgetary allocations for various activities.
The NAP establishes an inter-ministerial committee to drive the AMR agenda at the highest level of governance.
The NAP includes recommendations for regulations and enforcement related to antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes actions to incorporate information on antimicrobials into the curricula of training institutions.
The NAP outlines public education campaigns to promote responsible use of antimicrobials.
The NAP acknowledges support from WHO and FAO in its development and implementation.
The NAP includes plans to establish national monitoring systems for antimicrobial use and surveillance of antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP emphasizes the need for capacity building in surveillance and response to AMR.
The NAP includes strategies to reduce the incidence of infection through effective sanitation, hygiene, and infection prevention measures.
The NAP aligns with international standards and guidelines for AMR control as recommended by WHO, OIE, and FAO.
The NAP includes recommendations for regulating the distribution and prescription of antibiotics.
The NAP emphasizes the need for regulations to ensure the rational use of antibiotics.
The NAP encourages collaboration with international partners for research and development in AMR.
